data.event: The town's central settlement, where 4,456 people resided at the 2010 census (primarily Plymouth State students), is defined as the Plymouth census-designated place (CDP), and is located along U.S. Route 3, south of the confluence of the Baker and Pemigewasset rivers.

event.title: was burned to the ground by Captain Thomas Baker in 1712

data.event: Plymouth was originally the site of an Abenaki village that was burned to the ground by Captain Thomas Baker in 1712.
Parts of Hebron and Campton were annexed in 1845 and 1860.
